cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:38): Can anyone tell me why the <a> surrounding the <h1> is clickable in all the header? I don't get it. http://dl.dropbox.com/u/287771/ai/web/index.html
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:38): sighs that he love/hates linux
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:40): cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf: you wrapped an <a> around an <h1> - that'd make the whole thing an anchor, what's unexpected about this?
3e65db05e37f34bd21c82600a0356298 (20:40): on that, going to mozilla party for ff4 in paris :)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:40): 3e65db05e37f34bd21c82600a0356298: wearing an FF shirt they gave me on Tuesday right now! :)
cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:40): but I setted the h1     width: 401px;
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:41): needs to find ways to get some inexpensive/free tech shirts
3a11d663baf9dd49fd3266d53d9bec5c (20:41): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17, submit patches to Mozilla? :)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:41): cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf: don't matter - if you don't want something to be "clickable" then move the <a> tag <h1><a>inside the header</a></h1>
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:42): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17: work for Yahoo! in Santa Monica 3 days ago, :)
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:42): nees to find ways to gain more knowledge so he can fix bugs effectively
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:42): cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf: why do you think the *style* of an element has any relevance to a link‚Äôs behaviour?
cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:42): I used to do that, but as I've read that in html5 <a> can be surrounding block elements I wanted to give it a try
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf: you can surround things with <a>'s in HTML4 as well...
cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:43): I wan't it clicable, but with a fixed width
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:43): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: not block-level elements, not legally
cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:43): want*
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:43): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: hmmm, you sure?
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:43): at least one version of gecko falls over when you try to do that
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:44): because it wasn‚Äôt valid before html5
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:44): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: defaultly inline elements with display:block; in CSS legal, though, ya?
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:44): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: well, the markup is valid in that case, but it doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôll do what you think it is going to do
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:44): has set links to display block frequently
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:44): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: I could swear I'm doing that one one of my sites (and they all validate XHTML 1.0, but maybe that's diff...)
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:44): helps make whole areas clickable in navigation

cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:45): do you get why I mean? I thought I was explaining me badly. I do want the h1 to be clickable, as it must be a link, but I don't what its width expanding to it's container width
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:46): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: seems to work for me in every browser I've ever tried... (Firefox 2-4, IE6-9, Chrome, Opera 8+, Safari 2+)
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:46): set the h1 width to some number lower than the container width
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:46): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: that's obviously not an *exhaustive* list, though, as you have more and all of mobile
cd89c2b2cf9f8768dad9345bdc01a9bf (20:46): that's what I did 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:47): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: <a><h1>foo</h1></a>? or <a><span style="display:block">foo</span></a> ?
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:47): which is pretty awesome if you think about it, isn‚Äôt it?
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:47): that the latter works
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:47): and the former falls over
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:47): even though they are exactly the same
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:47): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: yeah, pretty much
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:47): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: tells you how easy it is to fool validators
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:48): you aren‚Äôt fooling a validator though
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:48): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: also, have found alot of other restrictions kinda lame...
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:48): the validator looks for semantically valid markup
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:48): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: guess you're right
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:48): the style of those elements is superfluous to that
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:48): goal
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:50): http://cdn.imgfave.com/image_cache2/1302725122200711.jpeg

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:51): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: it was always strange to me that <img> isn't block level by default - the use case for putting even moderately big images in text inline (without floating, etc.) seems kinda rare, IMO
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:51): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: (that's what I was thinking was block level and validates inside <a> tags, but they're not)

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:52): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: and if you think of a "block" semantically, you think of a square thing - and images only really exist in squares on the tubes, heh (as far as I know...?)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:53): i think what you most often want with is inline-block
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:54): 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780: historically images were small icons
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:54): not big
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:54): but inline-block has only been supported sanely relatively recently
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:54): in fact one of the original tag proposals was <icon> instead
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (20:54): i still have yet to really get inline-block
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:54): not much to get
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:55): i've never tried to fully understand CSS/HTML flow at a deep level, but I understand inline-block intuitively
c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3 (20:55): it‚Äôs a block element (width, height, margins) that gets placed inline flow
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:55): people often use ugly float layouts when they don't understand inline-block

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:56): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: it's sanely supported now that Hedger Wang found a cool hack to do it as old as IE6 (or maybe 5.5), so it's not too horrible, no
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:56): c2eb257d1afa6da62c7dd11790e063f3: yeah, that's what I figured
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:57): it was still pretty glitchy in IE6, iirc, but you can make it work

2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:57): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: http:/ 2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780.org/inline-block.html <-- yes, you're right, this is totally what I want my page to look like, :)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:57): (the weird *zoom: 1 or whatever hack, iirc?)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:57): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: display:inline-block;_zoom:1;_display:block; /* that'd be just 6, yeah */
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:57): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: not sure if you need it in 7 though
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (20:58): it's not a hack i memorize :P
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:58): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: or if you want valid CSS, conditional comments and .ie6 .ib { min-width: 0; display: block; }
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (20:59): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: (min-width also triggers hasLayout the same as zoom, pretty sure...)
3fa179c2d34f53c18e7551ac493014d9 (20:59): ah, good ol hasLayout
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:00): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: (or overflow:auto; etc. etc. etc.)
2360aabaa09d5610935ee7e2283f0780 (21:01): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: it's a hack I use whenever setting up a grid system or CSS framework
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:11): sigh: google images has some workaround for android's weirdo address bar, but I can't find anything about it so I have to reverse engineer the dumb thing
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (21:18): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: what does it do?
0acb83f1a9cfc48f061ff5555e61c6bf (21:18): "weirdo"?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:21): well, you can only scroll the address bar up off the screen if it thinks there's content on the page to scroll *down* into
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:21): which doesn't make sense for full-screen pages that just fill the window
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:21): the effect is that if you size a page to the window, you can't scroll the address bar up

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:22): ... the basic workaround is to add empty padding to the bottom and do scrollTo(0, 1), but that *animates* the scrolling down instead of snapping to the new position like a normal browser, which makes it hard to do cleanly--yet google images somehow does snap it off with no animation
